title: Rising sea levels could wipe out entire cities by 2050, scientists warn

Rising sea levels could see entire cities wiped out by 2050, a new study has warned.

Researchers from Climate Central found that hundreds of millions more people than previously thought live on land at risk from coastal flooding linked to climate change.

In the study, the researchers used a new digital elevation model called CoastelDEM to model the effect or rising sea levels over the next 30 years.

The model indicates that by 2050, land now home to 300 million people will be underwater, while land occupied by 150 million people will be wiped out entirely.

Most of these areas are in Asia, with 70% of the total number of people worldwide living on implicated land in China, Bangladesh, India, Vietnam, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Japan.

(Image: Climate Central)

However, the threat isn’t reduced to just Asia - the model predicts that 3.5 million people could be at risk of flooding here in the UK.

In a statement, Climate Central said: “Without augmented or new coastal defences, populations in these areas may face regular flooding or permanent inundation within 30 years.”

The researchers hope their findings will encourage coastal communities to prepare themselves for the future.

(Image: Science Photo Library RM)

In their study, published in Nature, the researchers wrote: “If our findings stand, coastal communities worldwide must prepare themselves for much more difficult futures than may be currently anticipated.”

Speaking to The Guardian, Benjamin Strauss, CEO at Climate Central, said: "The need for coastal defences and higher planning for higher seas is much greater than we thought if we are to avoid economic harm and instability.

"The silver lining to our research: although many more people are threatened than we thought, the benefits of action are greater.”
description: Researchers from Climate Central found that hundreds of millions more people than previously thought live on land at risk from coastal flooding linked to climate change
